title: Lesson Two
originalHtml:
Lesson Two in the Ranking Evidence lesson sequence introduces students to two shared texts that help them become aware of the topic. Students practice annotation with teacher support and write their initial claims about the issue.

For those that have taught or are currently teaching the lesson sequence, notice how your students engage with the lesson.

  • How did your students respond to the lesson?

  • What was most helpful for your students? What was challenging?

For those that are planning to teach the lesson sequence later this year, consider trying out the activities yourself and, based on your experience, reflect on how you imagine your students will engage with the lesson.

  • How do you think your students will respond to the lesson?

  • What do you imagine will be most helpful to them? What might be challenging?

Reflect and Share

Join the Lesson Two Discussion and reflect on the following:

  • If you are teaching the lesson sequence now or have already taught it, how did your students respond to the two shared readings? How did the annotation process go? Was there anything that was challenging to you or your students? Did anything surprise you? If possible, share a couple of student responses to the Exit Ticket.

  • If you are teaching the lesson sequence later this year, try out the activities in Lesson Two as a learner and share how it went. What worked for you? What was challenging? How do you imagine your students will respond to this lesson?

Looking Ahead: Preparation for Lesson Three

Lesson Three: Jigsaw

Depending on grade-level and students’ experience with reading, annotating, and discussion, this lesson may take 2 class periods. Be sure to plan accordingly and don’t rush students too much. Having said that, accountability to their peers is a central part of making a jigsaw work, so also don’t drag it on too long. There should be some sense of urgency in completing the activities to keep students moving forward.

It really helps streamline the jigsaw process to copy each of the texts in a different color. That way students can find like groups and mixed groups really easily. To prepare for a jigsaw, teachers typically divide the total number of students in the class by the total number of articles and make a couple additional copies of each one. For example, if you have a class of 35 students and 5 articles, you would make 9-10 copies of each.

There are a few strategies you might use for distributing the texts. Again, color-coding makes each of these approaches easier. :

  • Set the piles of articles out on a table and allow students to choose which one they want to read

  • If students are sitting in partners or groups, hand out the articles by group

  • If you have varied reading levels and want to differentiate, you can distribute articles based on that. The articles represent a range of lengths and levels of difficulty so a teacher can take this approach.

  • Be sure not to skip the step where students get to check in with someone else who read the same source as them. This is key to making sure everyone is successful in the jigsaw. Be sure to do this before you hand out the jigsaw note-catcher so they actually talk about the source rather than just copying each other.
